abstract.p: Howard G Goldberg appraises wines from Osprey's Dominion Vineyards in Peconic, NY (S)

block.p: On a chilly, gray day, with the thermometer dropping in late afternoon, the home-and-hearth prospect of a mug of steaming Osprey's Dominion Spice Wine raises the spirits.
On a chilly, gray day, with the thermometer dropping in late afternoon, the home-and-hearth prospect of a mug of steaming Osprey's Dominion Spice Wine raises the spirits.
The winery says it uses no artificial flavors, just ground cinnamon, cloves and nutmeg. Although the reds used (including merlot) were dry, the spices impart a sense of sweetness.

''When heating this wine,'' Osprey Dominion advises, ''do not boil it. Just warm it to the approximate temperature of a cup of coffee. Microwaving is also an excellent and quick way to heat the wine. If you are having a party, the wine can be kept in a Crock-Pot with a ladle.''

The nonvintage Spice Wine ($8 at Osprey's Dominion, Main Road, Peconic, on the north fork) is one of the winery's most popular products, said the winemaker, Peter Silverberg. It has been in its portfolio for several years.
The winery recommends the wine as a glaze for a ham and recommends marinating pork chops in it for about half an hour before cooking.
The steamy aroma brings to mind those innumerable scenes, in English novels, of a welcome bowl of punch that promotes good fellowship after the hunt.
